choices.text: Expectant management
Salpingectomy
Milking the tube
Inj Methotrexate

questions.text: A 28-y woman with a history of infertility for 3 years presents with 6 weeks amenorrhea. She has mild abdominal pain and spotting PV. Her UPT is weakly positive. On examination, she is hemodynamically stable. There is a 3 x 2.5 cm left sided adnexal lesion. Ultrasound reveals a left sided tubal gestational sac with no cardiac activity. Her βhCG is 2500 IU.  Which is the BEST management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Inj. Methotrexate

 

  • This is an ectopic pregnancy which is unruptured as the patient is stable and has mild pain
  • She fits into the criteria for medical management (Single dose Methotrexate 50 mg/m2)
  • Criteria for medical management includes
  1. Mild or no pain
  2. Serum beta hCG < 5000 IU
  3. Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm
  4. No cardiac activity
  5. Willing for follow up
  6. No c/I to MTx
  • If all the above criteria are fulfilled, it is an indication for medical management.

 

Ref: page no 379, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Ampulla
Infundibulum
Interstitial
Isthmus

questions.text: The most common site of tubal ectopic pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ampulla

 

Explanation:

 

  • Most common site for ectopic pregnancy: Fallopian tube
  • In the fallopian tube, Most common site is: Ampulla
  • Ampulla > Isthmus > Infundibulum > Interstitial
  • Other sites of ectopic pregnancy:
    • Ovarian
    • Cervical
    • Abdominal
    • Cornual
    • Cesarean scar pregnancy (incidence increasing)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Most common site for ectopic pregnancy: Fallopian tube
  • In the fallopian tube, Most common site is: Ampulla
  • Ampulla > Isthmus > Infundibulum > Interstitial

 

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Endometriosis
History of salpingitis
Previous ectopic pregnancy
Previous cesarean

questions.text: All are risk factors for tubal ectopic pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Previous cesarean

 

Explanation:

 

  • Previous cesarean section is NOT a risk factor for tubal ectopic pregnancy

 

Let’s Discuss all the other options:

 

  • Option A: Endometriosis affects tubal motility due to adhesions and thus increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy
  • Option B: Salpingitis is inflammation of the fallopian tube. A past h/o salpingitis may have led to tubal damage and hence affect tubal motility thereby leading to a higher risk of tubal ectopic
  • Option C: Previous h/o ectopic is also a risk factor for a repeat tubal ectopic as it means there is an underlying pathology

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk Factors of ectopic pregnancy

 

  • h/o Tubal Surgery (e.g., for fertility restoration or sterilization): As per Williams Obstetrics 25th edition (page 371): HIGHEST RISK
  • Prior h/o salpingitis: 6 – 10-fold increased risk
  • h/o previous ectopic: 5-fold risk (10 – 15% chance of repeat ectopic)
  • Peri tubal adhesions (like endometriosis)
  • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa
  • Congenital tubal anomalies
  • Infertility (artificial Reproductive techniques like IVF)
    • Associated with Atypical implantations and heterotopic pregnancies
  • Contraception: Relative numbers increased with intra-uterine devices (Absolute numbers decreased)
    • Intra uterine devices
    • Progesterone only pill

 

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: A
B
C
D

questions.text: Which part of the fallopian tube is the most caommon site of ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

Explanation:

 

  • Most common site for ectopic pregnancy is the fallopian tube
  • In the fallopian tube the most common site is Ampulla which is “C” on the image shown

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sites of tubal ectopic in order of occurrence are:
    • Ampulla > Isthmus > Infundibulum > Interstitial

 

 

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Endometriosis
History of tubal surgery
In vitro fertilization
Intra uterine device

questions.text: Risk of an ectopic pregnancy is highest with:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. History of tubal surgery

 

Explanation:

 

All the above-mentioned factors are risk factors for tubal ectopic with a h/o tubal surgery carrying the highest risk

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk Factors for tubal ectopic

 

  • h/o Tubal Surgery (e.g., for fertility restoration or sterilization): HIGHEST RISK
  • Prior h/o salpingitis: 6 – 10-fold increased risk
  • h/o previous ectopic: 5-fold risk (10 – 15% chance of repeat ectopic)
  • Peri tubal adhesions (like endometriosis)
  • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa
  • Congenital tubal anomalies
  • Infertility (ART)
    • Associated with Atypical implantations and heterotopic pregnancies
  • Contraception: Relative numbers increased with intra-uterine devices (Absolute numbers decreased)

 

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: The incidence of heterotopic pregnancy is decreasing due to early diagnosis
Atypical sites of ectopics are decreasing due to IVF
The incidence of an ectopic increases by about 50% following a history of ectopic
The relative incidence of ectopic pregnancy is increased with the use of intrauterine devices.

questions.text: Which is correct regarding ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. The relative incidence of ectopic pregnancy is increased with the use of intrauterine devices.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all the options:

 

  • Option A: The incidence of heterotopic pregnancy is decreasing due to early diagnosis: This is incorrect. The incidence of heterotopic pregnancy is increasing due to increasing incidence of Assisted Reproductive Techniques.
  • Option B: Atypical sites of ectopics are decreasing due to IVF: This is also incorrect. Atypical sites of ectopic pregnancy like cervical pregnancy, ovarian pregnancy etc. are increasing due to IVF
  • Option C: The incidence of an ectopic increases by about 50% following a history of ectopic. This is also incorrect as the incidence of an ectopic pregnancy increases by 10-15% following a prior ectopic.
  • Option D: The relative incidence of ectopic pregnancy is increased with the use of intrauterine devices. This is correct. With use of intra-uterine devices, the overall pregnancy rate is reduced but if a woman conceives with an IUD, it is important to note that the ectopic rate is high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk Factors

 

  • h/o Tubal Surgery (e.g., for fertility restoration or sterilization): HIGHEST RISK
  • Prior h/o salpingitis: 6 – 10-fold increased risk
  • h/o previous ectopic: 5-fold risk (10 – 15% chance of repeat ectopic)
  • Peri tubal adhesions (like endometriosis)
  • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa
  • Congenital tubal anomalies
  • Infertility (ART)
    • Associated with Atypical implantations and heterotopic pregnancies
    • Heterotopic pregnancies and heterotopic pregnancies are increasing due to this
  • Contraception: Relative numbers increased with intra-uterine devices (Absolute numbers decreased)

 

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Dilatation and evacuation
Shift to the O.T. for an emergency laparotomy
Urgent ultrasound
Urgent serum βhCG

questions.text: A 24y lady presented to the emergency with generalized pain and spotting PV. Her LMP was 2 months back and she has a history of irregular cycles. On examination, she is pale, her PR is 110/ min, BP is 80/60 mmHg. There is guarding and rigidity on abdominal examination and a vaginal exam reveals cervical motion tenderness. Her urine pregnancy test is weakly positive. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shift to the O.T. for an emergency laparotomy

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is most likely a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. A RUPTURED ectopic pregnancy is a clinical diagnosis.
  • Whenever there is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy with the patient in shock (hypotension, tachycardia), no time is to be wasted and the patient should be shifted to the OT for an emergency laparoscopy/ laparotomy and salpingectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Dilatation and evacuation: This is not done in an ectopic pregnancy
  • Option C: Doing an ultrasound (no matter how urgently in a patient with shock) will cause a delay and worsen patient prognosis
  • Option D: Beta hCG (even urgent will take a few hours) is not indicated in a ruptured ectopic. It only has a role in an unruptured ectopic

 

Educational Objective:

 

D/d of bleeding in the 1st trimester

 

  1. Implantation bleeding (Placental Sign)
  2. Abortion (threatened, inevitable, incomplete, complete, missed)
  3. Ectopic Pregnancy
  4. Molar pregnancy
  • Classic triad of symptoms I.e., pain, bleeding and delayed menstruation is seen in an ectopic pregnancy.
  • In this scenario there is pain and bleeding with a positive pregnancy test and on examination there is pallor, shock and intraperitoneal bleed which points to a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • Next best management option is immediate surgical management and salpingectomy

 

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 2,3,4,1
2,3,1,4
3,2,1,4
3,2,4,1

questions.text:
Arrange the following ectopic sites in decreasing order of occurrence.

 

  1. Interstitial
  2. Isthmus
  3. Ampulla
  4. Infundibulum
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 3,2,4,1

 

Explanation:

 

  • The most common site for ectopic pregnancy: Fallopian tube
    • In the fallopian tube, the most common site is: Ampulla
    • Ampulla > Isthmus > Infundibulum > Interstitial

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site for ectopic pregnancy: Fallopian tube
    • In the fallopian tube, the most common site is: Ampulla
    • Ampulla > Isthmus > Infundibulum > Interstitial

 

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Pain, bleeding, pallor
Pain, delayed menstruation, pallor
Bleeding, pain, delayed menstruation
Pallor, pain, delayed menstruation

questions.text: The classic triad of clinical features in an ectopic pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bleeding, pain, delayed menstruation

 

Explanation:

 

  • Clinical Features of an ectopic pregnancy vary but is typically characterized by the classic triad of
    1. Delayed menstruation
    2. Abdominal pain
    3. Vaginal Bleeding

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clinical Features of an ectopic pregnancy vary but is typically characterized by the classic triad of
    • Delayed menstruation
    • Abdominal pain
    • Vaginal Bleeding
  • Other symptoms may include:
    • Passage of a decidual cast
    • Severe hemoperitoneum: diaphragmatic irritation – shoulder pain
    • Pallor, Shock – uterine rupture
    • Abdominal tenderness
    • Bimanual exam: cervical motion tenderness
    • Tender boggy mass in the post fornix (collected blood)
    • Cullen’s sign: Periumbilical bluish discoloration due to intraperitoneal bleeding

choices.text: Eccentrically located
Irregular
Yolk sac not seen
Intra-decidual sign not seen

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding a pseudo sac?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Eccentrically located

 

Explanation:

 

  • A pseudo sac is seen in ectopic pregnancies. It is intrauterine fluid collection which gives the appearance of an intra-uterine gestational sac.
  • A pseudo sac is CENTRAL, irregular and no yolk sac or fetal pole is seen. The intra-decidual and double ring sign are absent

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Bagel sign
Blob sign
Lemon sign
Tubal ring

questions.text: All are ultrasound signs of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lemon sign

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all the Options:

 

  • Option A: Bagel sign: This is a ‘bagel’ or doughnut shaped structure seen in the adnexa on ultrasound typical of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Option B: Blob sign: This is also a sign seen in ectopic pregnancy wherein a Heteroechoic structure is seen in the adnexal region
  • Option C: Lemon sign: This is a sign seen in spina bifida which shows pinching of the calvarium
  • Option D: Tubal ring: This is a ring like structure on ultrasound seen in ectopic pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Suspected unruptured ectopic pregnancy: Trans-vaginal Sonography (TVS) will reveal

 

  • An absent intra-uterine pregnancy
  • The presence of a pseudo-sac in the uterine cavity
  • The presence of an adnexal mass separate from the ovary
    • Hyperechoic ring surrounding an anechoic sac- seen in 20% (bagel sign/tubal ring sign)
    • Inhomogeneous mass – 60% (blob sign)
    • Obvious gestational sac with a fetal pole – 13%
  • On color doppler: “Ring of fire” seen. (D/d – Corpus luteal cyst)

 

Ref: page no 375, William Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Corpus luteal cyst, Circle of fire sign
Corpus luteal cyst, Ring of fire sign.
Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Circle of fire sign
Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign

questions.text: A 30-year lady presented to the gyn OPD with complaints of mild abdominal pain and spotting. She gives a history of delayed menses by about 7 days. Her UPT is faintly positive. An ultrasound with color doppler reveals the following image. What is the diagnosis and what is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign

 

Explanation:

 

  • The patient’s history is suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy (classic triad of pain, bleeding and delayed menstruation is there)
  • The image shows the classical “ring of fire” sign which is peri-trophoblastic vascularity.
  • Other options:
    • Corpus luteal cyst, Circle of fire sign: A corpus luteal cyst can present with vascularity around it on Doppler and appear like the ing of fire, not circle of fire
    • Corpus luteal cyst, Ring of fire sign: This could be a close differential to the question given but, in the question, the classic triad of ectopic is also mentioned which will not be seen in a corpus luteal cyst
    • Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Circle of fire sign: The name of the sign is “Ring of fire”

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

  • The above image showing vascularity around a sac like structure is called the ring of fire sign and is seen in unruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

Ref: page no 376, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: The level above which an ectopic gestational sac should be visualized
The level below which an ectopic gestational sac should be visualized
The level above which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be visualized
The level below which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be visualized

questions.text: What is the discriminatory zone for βhCG?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The level above which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be visualized

 

Explanation

 

  • Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen,
    • 1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS
    • 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS
  • There is another concept of hCG called doubling time. This means that βhCG levels should double every 48h in early pregnancy in a normal intra-uterine pregnancy. Actually, doubling is a misnomer. The rise in βhCG should be >60% at least in 48h.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen,
    • 1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS
    • 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS

 

Ref: page no 373, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 500 IU/L
1500 IU/L
2500 IU/L
3500 IU/L

questions.text: The value of βhCG above which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be seen is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1500 IU/L

 

Explanation:

 

Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen,

 

  • 1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS
  • 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen,
    • 1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS
    • 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS

 

Ref: page no 373, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Complete abortion
Ectopic pregnancy
Pregnancy of undetermined location
Pseudocyesis

questions.text: A 33-year woman comes to the OPD with amenorrhea of 6 weeks. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. A transvaginal ultrasound is done which shows normal uterus and adnexa. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pregnancy of undetermined location

 

Explanation:

 

This is a PREGNANCY OF UNKNOWN LOCATION (PUL):  No sign of an intra or extra uterine pregnancy on ultrasound despite a positive pregnancy test

 

Let’s discuss all the options:

 

  • Option A: Complete abortion: This is unlikely a complete abortion as there is no history of vaginal bleeding or passage of a tissue.
  • Option B: Ectopic pregnancy: This could be a possibility but there is nothing in the scenario which is suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy
  • Option C: Pregnancy of unknown location: This is what this scenario is. A pregnancy of unknown or undetermined location (PUL) means the urine or serum bhCG is positive but the ultrasound does not show an intra uterine or extra uterine gestational sac.
  • Option D: Pseudocyesis: This is phantom pregnancy. In this the urine pregnancy test will be negative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: page no 373, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: A failing intrauterine pregnancy
A Hydatiform mole
A recent complete abortion
An ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: A 20y G2A1 presents at 6 weeks pregnancy with vaginal bleeding. On TVS, no gestational sac is visualized. Her serum βhCG is 2000 IU/L. Which is NOT a possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A Hydatiform mole

 

Explanation:

 

  • Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen,
    • 1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS
    • 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS
  • So, if serum βhCG levels are more than the discriminatory zone and still an intrauterine gestational sac is not seen on ultrasound, it is called a pregnancy of undetermined location & the following should be suspected:
    • Ectopic pregnancy
    • Failing intrauterine pregnancy
    • Recent complete abortion
    • Early multifetal pregnancy

 

Other option

 

  • In molar pregnancy, the βhCG levels are very high (usually > 100,000)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • If serum βhCG levels are more than the discriminatory zone and still an intrauterine gestational sac is not seen on ultrasound, it is called a pregnancy of undetermined location & the following should be suspected:
    • Ectopic pregnancy
    • Failing intrauterine pregnancy
    • Recent complete abortion
    • Early multifetal pregnancy

 

Ref: page no 374, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Mild abdominal pain
Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm with no cardiac activity
Clinically stable
βhCG < 1000 IU/L

questions.text: All are indications for expectant management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mild abdominal pain

 

Explanation:

 

Expectant Management: This means no active intervention; just following up the patient with βhCG levels. Mild pain is NOT an indication for expectant management. There should be NO pain.

  • Only for clinically stable asymptomatic women with an ultrasound diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy with the following features
  1. Clinically stable with No pain AND
  2. Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L AND
  3. Tubal ectopic < 35mm with no visible heartbeat AND
  4. Able to return for follow up
  • Repeat βhCG levels on days 2, 4 and 7 after the original test
  • If βhCG levels drop ≥ 15% from the previous values, then repeat weekly till a negative result
  • If values fall < 15%, stay the same or rise from the previous value, review the condition and consider shifting to medical/ surgical management

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Expectant Management of ectopic pregnancy (i.e. no active intervention; just following up the patient with βhCG levels); the following criteria should be fulfilled:

 

Only for clinically stable asymptomatic women with an ultrasound diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy with the following features

 

  • Clinically stable with No pain AND
  • Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L AND
  • Tubal ectopic < 35mm with no visible heartbeat AND
  • Able to return for follow up

 

Ref: page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

choices.text: Expectant management
Single dose inj Methotrexate
Laparoscopic salpingostomy
Laparoscopic salpingectomy

questions.text: A 34-year woman presents to the gyn OPD with an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. She has no symptoms and is hemodynamically stable. Her βhCG is 600 IU/L. The ultrasound shows a gestational sac measuring 20 mm in the right adnexa with no yolk sac or embryo seen. Which of these is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Expectant management

 

Explanation:

 

This patient fulfills all the criteria for Expectant management, i.e. no active intervention needs to be done. Just following up with weekly beta hCG levels (it should decrease every week)

 

Let’s discuss the other options

 

  • Option B: Single dose inj Methotrexate: This is medical management and is indicated in an unruptured ectopic pregnancy with:
  1. Patient hemodynamically stable
  2. No significant symptoms
  3. Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm
  4. No visible cardiac activity
  5. Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L
  6. No contraindication to Methotrexate (Anemia, liver disease, bleeding disorder, active pulmonary disease etc.)
  • Option C and D: Laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy: Surgical management in an unruptured ectopic is indicated in a woman with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy with
  1. Significant pain OR
  2. Gestational sac size > 3.5 cm OR
  3. Visible cardiac activity on ultrasound OR
  4. Hemodynamically unstable patient OR
  5. Beta hCG > 5000 IU/L
  • The choice between salpingotomy or salpingectomy is made based on the following: Salpingectomy (Removing the whole tube) is preferred In women whose family is complete, if the tube is grossly distorted anatomically, if the ectopic has happened at the sire of a previous ectopic or at the site of a previous tubal ligation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Expectant Management

 

  • Only for clinically stable asymptomatic women with an ultrasound diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy with the following features
  1. Clinically stable with No pain AND
  2. Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L AND
  3. Tubal ectopic < 35mm with no visible heartbeat AND
  4. Able to return for follow up
  • Repeat βhCG levels on days 2, 4 and 7 after the original test
  • If βhCG levels drop ≥ 15% from the previous values, then repeat weekly till a negative result
  • If values fall < 15%, stay the same or rise from the previous value, review the condition and consider shifting to medical/ surgical management

 

Ref: page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

choices.text: Patient hemodynamically stable
Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm
Visible cardiac activity
Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L

questions.text: All are indications for medical management of an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Visible cardiac activity

 

Explanation:

 

Medical Management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy (Inj Methotrexate) is given in the following:

 

Indications: An unruptured ectopic pregnancy with:

 

  1. Patient hemodynamically stable
  2. No significant symptoms
  3. Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm
  4. No visible cardiac activity
  5. Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L
  6. No contraindication to Methotrexate (Anemia, liver disease, bleeding disorder, active pulmonary disease etc.)

 

Hence Option C is the correct option as if visible cardiac activity is present, it will not be given.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical Management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy (Inj Methotrexate) is given in the following:

 

Indications: An unruptured ectopic pregnancy with:

 

  1. Patient hemodynamically stable
  2. No significant symptoms
  3. Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm
  4. No visible cardiac activity
  5. Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L
  6. No contraindication to Methotrexate (Anemia, liver disease, bleeding disorder, active pulmonary disease etc.)

 

Ref: Page no 377, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Methotrexate
Mifepristone
Misoprostol
Potassium chloride

questions.text: The drug of choice for medical management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Methotrexate

 

Explanation:

 

  • The drug of choice for treatment of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is Methotrexate.
  • MOA: Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
  • 2 protocols: Single dose and Multidose
  • Usually, the single dose regime is sufficient, very rarely another dose is required.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B: Mifepristone: This is also known as RU486 and is a selective progesterone receptor modulator with strong anti-progestogenic action. It is commonly used in medical methods of termination of pregnancy along with misoprostol in 1st and 2nd trimester.
  • Option C: Misoprostol: This is PGE1 and is a uterotonic. It induces uterine contractions and is therefore used in medical methods of termination of pregnancy, induction of labor and prophylaxis and management of atonic PPH.
  • Option D: KCl: Ultrasound guided Intracardiac injection of Kcl is used in selective fetal termination in multifetal pregnancy reduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The drug of choice for treatment of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is Methotrexate.
  • MOA: Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
  • 2 protocols: Single dose and Multidose
  • Usually, the single dose regime is sufficient, very rarely another dose is required.
  • 2 regimes:

 

 

Ref: Page no 377, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Endometrial biopsy
Cervical biopsy
Culdocentesis
Pap smear

questions.text: Identify this procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Culdocentesis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shows the procedure of culdocentesis.
  • In the absence of TVS and if the diagnosis of a ruptured ectopic is still in doubt: Culdocentesis can be done:
  1. Simple technique
  2. Cervix pulled outward and upward (holding a tenaculum/ vulsullum) on the posterior cervix.
  3. 18-gauge needle is inserted in the posterior fornix
  4. Aspiration of non-clotting blood signifies hemoperitoneum
  5. A negative Culdocentesis does not rule out a ruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Endometrial biopsy: In this procedure, a sample is taken from inside the uterine cavity (endometrial) using an endometrial aspirator
  • Option B. Cervical biopsy: In this a biopsy is taken from the cervix/ cervical growth using a punch biopsy forceps
  • Option D. Pap smear: In this procedure, using an instrument called an Ayre’s spatula, a smear is taken from the ectocervix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • The procedure shown in this image is a culdocentesis. It is aspiration of fluid from the Pouch of Douglas and if blood is aspirated, it means there is hemoperitoneum

 

Ref: page no 376, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Laparoscopic salpingectomys
Laparoscopic salpingostomy
Inj Methotrexate single dose
Inj methotrexate multiple dose

questions.text: A 24y old lady with a history of a tubal sterilization is diagnosed to have an unruptured ectopic pregnancy of size 4 cm. Serum βhCG is 6000 IU/L. The preferred management option is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Laparoscopic salpingectomy

 

Explanation:

 

  • This woman is not a candidate for medical management as the size is > 3.5 cm and βhCG is > 3000 IU/L.
  • She requires surgical management: In an unruptured ectopic: Laparoscopy is preferred and, in this woman, a salpingectomy (removing the tube) is preferred to a salpingostomy (conserving the tube) as the patient has a h/o tubal ligation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: Laparoscopic salpingostomy: This is not preferred in this patient as if the ectopic pregnancy has happened at the site of a previous tubal ligation, it is better to remove the tube as it can keep recurring in this fallopian tube.
  • Option C: Inj Methotrexate single dose: This is also not preferred as in this scenario the beta hCG is > 5000 and the sac size is > 3.5 cm so she is not a candidate for medical management
  • Option D: Inj methotrexate multiple doses: This is also not preferred as in this scenario the beta hCG is > 5000 and the sac size is > 3.5 cm so she is not a candidate for medical management whether single or multi dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Criteria for surgical management (Laparoscopic salpingectomy or salpingotomy) in a patient with unruptured ectopic is:

 

  1. Significant pain OR
  2. Gestational sac size > 3.5 cm OR
  3. Visible cardiac activity on ultrasound OR
  4. Hemodynamically unstable patient OR
  5. Beta hCG > 5000 IU/L

 

How to decide whether to do a salpingostomy or a salpingectomy?

 

  • SALPINGECTOMY: Preferred if:
    • Extensive tubal involvement/ damage
    • Recurrent ectopic pregnancy in the same tube
    • Completed family
    • Ectopic at the site of a previous tubal sterilization
  • SALPINGOSTOMY: (Linear incision on the antimesenteric border with removal of products of conception)
  • Consider if a woman has other infertility factors also OR has a contralateral damaged/removed tube and wants to conceive in the future

 

 

Ref: page no 379, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Salpingectomy
Salpingostomy
Tubal recanalization
Tubal sterilization

questions.text: Identify this procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Salpingostomy

 

Explanation:

 

  • The procedure shown is a laparoscopic salpingostomy
  • It is done in an unruptured ectopic where the fallopian tube needs to be conserved

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Salpingectomy: This is removal of the entire fallopian tube
  • Option C. Tubal recanalization: This is joining the tubes together and is usually done following a tubal ligation when patient desires restoration of fertility
  • Option D. Tubal sterilization: This is ligating and/or cutting the fallopian tubes for permanent sterilization

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page 176, JC Dutta Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Abdominal pregnancy
Cervical pregnancy
Cornual pregnancy
Ovarian pregnancy

questions.text: Rubin criteria is for:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cervical pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all the options:

 

  • Rubin criteria – Cervical pregnancy
  • Spiegelberg criteria – Ovarian pregnancy
  • Studdiford criteria – Primary abdominal pregnancy
  • Cornual pregnancy – no named criteria

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rubin criteria – Cervical pregnancy
  • Spiegelberg criteria – Ovarian pregnancy
  • Studdiford criteria – Primary abdominal pregnancy

 

Ref: Page no 383, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

Ans. D. Ovarian pregnancy

  • Spiegelberg criteria – Ovarian pregnancy
  • Studdiford criteria – Primary abdominal pregnancy

choices.text: < 5000 IU/L
< 6000 IU/L
< 7000 IU/L
< 10000 IU/L

questions.text: Medical management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is recommended when the serum βhCG is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. < 5000 IU/L

 

Explanation

 

  • Indications for medical management of unruptured ectopic pregnancy:
  1. Patient hemodynamically stable
  2. No significant symptoms
  3. Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm
  4. No visible cardiac activity
  5. Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L
  6. No contraindication to Methotrexate (Anemia, liver disease, bleeding disorder, active pulmonary disease etc.)
  • Failure rate of medical management is about 4% if βhCG < 5000 IU/ but increases to 14% if βhCG is 10000 IU/L
  • Hence the correct option is < 5000 IU/L

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Indications for medical management of unruptured ectopic pregnancy:
  1. Patient hemodynamically stable
  2. No significant symptoms
  3. Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm
  4. No visible cardiac activity
  5. Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L
  6. No contraindication to Methotrexate (Anemia, liver disease, bleeding disorder, active pulmonary disease etc.)

 

Ref: Page no 377, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Expectant
Medical
Surgical
Medical + Surgical

questions.text: The preferred treatment in heterotopic pregnancy with a viable intra-uterine pregnancy with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Surgical

 

Explanation:

 

  • Incidence of heterotopic pregnancy: increasing due to ART
  • Treatment of choice: Surgical i.e. laparoscopic salpingectomy/ salpingostomy
  • Medical management with methotrexate is contra-indicated as it will kill the intrauterine pregnancy also

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Expectant management is not preferred in a heterotopic pregnancy
  • Option B: Medical management: Medical management with methotrexate is contra-indicated as it will kill the intrauterine pregnancy also
  • Option D: Medical + Surgical: There is no role of both medical and surgical management in a heterotopic pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A heterotopic pregnancy is an intra uterine pregnancy with an ectopic pregnancy
  • Incidence of heterotopic pregnancy: increasing due to ART
  • Treatment of choice: Surgical i.e. laparoscopic salpingectomy/ salpingostomy
  • Medical management with methotrexate is contra-indicated as it will kill the intrauterine pregnancy also

 

Ref: page no 142, Textbook of Obstetrics JB Sharma

choices.text: Interstitial tubal pregnancies rupture at very early gestational ages of 6-8 weeks
Both single dose and multi dose methotrexate are acceptable regimes for medical management
If single dose methotrexate is given, serum βhCG is checked on days 4 and 7
A woman who has had a previous ectopic pregnancy has a 5-fold increased risk of a repeat ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: All are true regarding unruptured tubal pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Interstitial tubal pregnancies rupture at very early gestational ages of 6-8 weeks

 

Explanation

 

  • Ectopic pregnancy in the isthmic region rupture earliest (6 weeks)
  • Ectopic pregnancy in the interstitial area rupture at 12 – 16 weeks as they can grow into the uterine portion

 

Ref: Page no 132, Textbook of Obstetrics, JB Sharma
